journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Reconstruction of a Bony Bankart Lesion
title-group.subtitle: Best Fit Based on Radius of Curvature

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedics and Rehabilitation, Oregon Health and Science University, Portland, Oregon
Investigation performed at Oregon Health and Science University, Portland, Oregon

author-notes.corresp: *Dennis Crawford, MD, PhD, Department of Orthopaedics and Rehabilitation, Oregon Health and Science University, 3181 Southwest Sam Jackson Park Road, Portland, OR 97239-3098 (e-mail: crawfden@ohsu.edu).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The inferior coracoid process has traditionally been considered to be the gold standard for glenoid augmentation after anteroinferior bone loss. Other autograft sites, and more recently, osteochondral allograft sites, have been described as potential donor sources.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: Potential autograft and osteochondral allograft sites were compared to identify the graft source that would provide the best fit for glenoid augmentation.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Controlled laboratory study.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Mose circles, a geometric tool found on a standard goniometer, were used to make radius of curvature measurements of 10 anatomic locations in 17 cadaveric specimens. The bony surface of the glenoid, measured from superior to inferior (G-SI) and from anterior to posterior (G-AP), was used as the standard for comparison. Autograft sites were the inferior coracoid, lateral coracoid, and inner table of the iliac crest. Potential osteochondral allograft sites were the radial head, scaphoid fossa of the distal radius (S-DR), lunate fossa of the distal radius (L-DR), medial tibial plateau, and lateral distal tibia. An acceptable match for autograft sites was based on a paired analysis and defined as a radius of curvature within 5 mm of the G-SI or the G-AP of the same cadaveric specimen. Allograft sites were evaluated using an unpaired analysis in which an ideal fit was defined as a radius of curvature of 25 to 30 mm, based on the interquartile range of the G-SI and G-AP.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The median (interquartile range) radii of curvature for the G-SI and G-AP were 30 mm (range, 25-30 mm) and 25 mm (range, 25-25 mm), respectively. The inferior coracoid was within 5 mm of the G-SI 59% of the time and the G-AP 94% of the time; no measurements from the lateral coracoid or iliac crest were within the range of the glenoid radius of curvature. Analysis of the allograft sites demonstrated an acceptable fit for 94% of the distal tibia, 68% of the medial tibial plateau, 12% of the S-DR, and 0% of the L-DR and the radial head specimens.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: An autograft of the inferior coracoid or an osteochondral allograft of the lateral distal tibia provided the best match to re-establish the native radius of curvature of the glenoid.

sec.title: Clinical Relevance:
sec.p: To best re-create the native glenohumeral anatomy, surgeons should consider the use of an autograft of the inferior coracoid or an osteochondral allograft of the lateral distal tibia for the reconstruction of osseous glenoid defects.

body.p: Anterior shoulder instability events are known to cause both soft tissue and bony defects that may require surgical stabilization to prevent further episodes of instability.2,7,17,23,28,29 The main indication for bony augmentation is a significant osseous defect, which has been defined as (1) an “inverted pear” glenoid with 20% to 25% anterior glenoid bone loss or (2) an engaging humeral head lesion.4,20 For the so-called bony Bankart lesions—a misnomer, as by definition these are osteochondral injuries—restoration of the glenoid structure allows the otherwise unstable glenohumeral joint to resist both the axial and shear forces acting upon it.4,16,22,33,34

Classically, the principal autogenous donor site has been the coracoid process, which has resulted in favorable clinical results and low recurrent instability events.1,3,5,14,18,21 The Bristow procedure involves transferring the coracoid process on-end to the anterior inferior glenoid,11 while the Latarjet procedure involves the coracoid being rotated so that its curved undersurface is congruous with the concave glenoid.19 The Bristow and Latarjet procedures create a larger glenoid surface via nonanatomic glenohumeral restoration. Although these are often clinically successful at maintaining glenohumeral stability, varying reports have noted the occurrence of complications and resultant functional deficits from these procedures.‡ As a result, surgeons have pursued other donor sites, which include the autogenous iliac crest,31 and more recently, several different osteochondral allograft sources such as the lateral distal tibia,24 glenoid,26,30 and femoral head.32 An advantage unique to the use of osteochondral allografts is the ability to provide osteochondral restoration of the articular surface defect. Short-term and midterm reports of both the iliac crest and the various osteochondral allografts have shown promising clinical outcomes.6,24-26,30-32

Several studies have addressed the anatomic shape of the glenoid, humeral head, and other potential donor sites for their compatibility.8-10,15,24 These studies separately report similar congruity of the glenoid with either the lateral distal tibia or the undersurface of the coracoid process.9,10,24 However, we are unaware of a comparison of the conformity of multiple autograft or potential osteochondral allograft sites to the glenoid in a single study. Therefore, the purpose of our study was to use direct measurements from cadaveric specimens to determine the relative congruence among potential osseous and osteochondral sites for glenoid augmentation in the setting of glenoid bone loss from anterior glenohumeral instability. We hypothesized that the radius of curvature measurements from the inferior coracoid and distal tibia would provide the closest match to that of the native glenoid.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: A total of 27 cadaveric specimens were available to compare the radii of curvature in 10 different anatomic sites. The glenoid, measured in both the superior to inferior (G-SI) and anterior to posterior (G-AP) planes, was used as the standard to which graft measurements were compared. The 3 autograft sources were the inferior surface of the coracoid, the lateral surface of the coracoid, and the inner table of the iliac crest (measured approximately 3 cm proximal to the anterior superior iliac spine, from medial to lateral, as described by Warner et al31). Five osteochondral allograft sources were used, consisting of the lateral aspect of the distal tibia (measured from anterior to posterior), the medial tibial plateau (in the coronal plane from the medial tibial spine to the midportion of the articular surface), the lunate fossa of the distal radius (L-DR; measured from anterior to posterior), the scaphoid fossa of the distal radius (S-DR; measured from medial to lateral), and the radial head. The lateral aspect of the distal tibia has been previously described in the literature9,24; the other 4 sites were chosen based on their size and theoretical radius of curvature as potential sites to match the glenoid.

Ten cadaveric specimens were excluded from the study because of the presence of joint arthroplasty (n = 3) or arthrosis (n = 7) at 1 or more of the 10 sites. Because of the anonymity requirements of the Department of Anatomy at our institution, any specific cause of significant articular erosion that precluded accurate measurement was unknown but was suspected to be from infection, avascular necrosis, osteoarthritis, or inflammatory arthritis. This left a total of 17 cadaveric specimens with preserved cartilaginous and bony architecture available for review. For each potential autograft and allograft site, both right and left sides were harvested, allowing for 34 specimens from each location for evaluation.

During cadaveric dissection, all soft tissue attachments, including the glenoid labrum, were removed such that the most accurate measurements could be taken. Bilateral measurements were taken at each anatomic site. Measurements were made with Mose circles, a standard geometric tool found on most goniometers to determine an object’s radius of curvature (Figure 1).10 One standard 8-inch AO-ASIF (Arbeitsgemeinshaft für Osteosynthesefragen [Association for the Study of Internal Fixation], Solothurn, Switzerland) goniometer was used for this study. Positive models of Mose circles were replicated from the goniometer in 2.5-mm increments, ranging from 10 mm through 35 mm, and were used for the measurements. The measurements were made independently for each specimen by 2 authors (A.D. and J.M.); any disparities were resolved at the time of initial measurement.

caption.p: Example of Mose circle measurements on the distal tibia using a standard goniometer. The osteotomized distal tibia is viewed in the sagittal plane, from lateral to medial.

sec.p: Of the 17 cadaveric specimens used in this study, 10 were male and 7 were female. The mean ± standard deviation (SD) age at the time of death was 77.8 ± 13.3 years, height was 67.3 ± 3.8 inches, and weight was 159.7 ± 24.1 lb. Reasons for death included cancer (n = 7), cardiovascular disease (n = 4), respiratory disease (n = 4), complications of Alzheimer’s disease (n = 1), and unknown (n = 1). Information on inflammatory arthritis or other articular diseases was not available.

A priori power analysis using results from a previous study demonstrated that a sample size of 17 cadaveric specimens was adequate for achieving a probability of 80% of not falsely rejecting the null hypothesis.9 For each anatomic site and corresponding radius of curvature, both the mean ± SD and median (interquartile range) were calculated. The radius of curvature was measured on a continuous ordinal scale of 2.5-mm increments. A multivariate analysis was performed to analyze for differences in radius of curvature measurements at each anatomic site to determine any differences with respect to patient age, sex, height, or weight. Significance was set at P < .05.

Autograft comparisons were made using paired statistics. Each of the 3 anatomic sites was compared with the glenoid measurements of the same cadaveric specimen. The absolute value of the difference in millimeters between the potential autograft site and the glenoid measurement was calculated, assuming that an overly large radius of curvature is as detrimental as an overly small radius of curvature. Assessment for equivalent augmentation between the 3 autograft sources and the glenoid (both G-SI and G-AP) was based on ±5 mm from the glenoid’s radius of curvature of the same cadaveric specimen. This number was chosen based on the SD and interquartile range of the glenoid’s radius of curvature; using 5 mm as a cutoff would allow for a comparable fit to augment the glenoid curvature in the majority of patients. A Fisher exact test was then performed to evaluate for statistical differences between autograft sites, with significance set at P < .05.

Allograft comparisons were made using an unpaired analysis, as each allograft site is independent of the patient’s glenoid. To determine which allograft specimens provided a consistent fit with the glenoid, a simple count of the total number of allograft specimens at each of the 5 sites that were found to be within the interquartile range of the glenoid’s radius of curvature was performed. This allowed for the determination of the percentage of specimens that would have an “ideal fit” for glenoid augmentation at each site in the majority of patients undergoing such a procedure.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The radius of curvature measurements between male and female cadaveric specimens did not differ significantly in any of the anatomic sites. Similarly, of all comparisons of right- and left-sided measurements, only 2 (<1.5%) were discordant in their finding: 1 cadaveric specimen showed a side-to-side asymmetry of 2.5 mm for the G-AP and lateral coracoid measurements. Given the overall equivalence in sex and sidedness, the cumulative data from both sexes and left and right sides were combined for a total of 34 measurements at each site.

The mean and median radii of curvature, with the corresponding SDs and interquartile ranges, for the glenoid, autograft, and allograft specimens are shown in Table 1. A pictorial representation of the range of measurements, along with the mean measurements, can be found in Figure 2. The SD and interquartile range for the iliac crest were not available, as all measurements were >35 mm and beyond the upper limit of the Mose circle measurements. Importantly, the radius of curvature of each anatomic site was found to be independent of the age, sex, height, or weight of the cadaveric specimen (P > .05) (see the Appendix, available in the online version of this article at http://ajsm.sagepub.com/supplemental).

caption.p: Mean and Median Radius of Curvature for Each Anatomic Site a

fn.label: a
fn.p: IQR, interquartile range; N/A, not applicable; SD, standard deviation.

caption.p: Range of radius of curvature measurements at each anatomic site. Δ = mean value. G-SI, glenoid superior-inferior; G-AP, glenoid anterior-posterior; Inf C, inferior coracoid; Lat C, lateral coracoid; IC, iliac crest; Dist T, distal tibia; MTP, medial tibial plateau; S-DR, scaphoid fossa of distal radius; L-DR, lunate fossa of distal radius; RH, radial head.

sec.title: Autograft Site Analysis
sec.p: Equivalent glenoid augmentation from different autograft sites was determined to be within 5 mm of the glenoid’s median radius of curvature. The paired analysis revealed that the inferior coracoid matched the G-SI 59% (20/34 specimens) of the time and matched the G-AP 94% (32/34 specimens) of the time (Table 2). No measurements from the lateral coracoid or iliac crest were within 5 mm of the glenoid’s radius of curvature. Statistical analysis revealed that the 3 autograft sites were significantly different from each other (P < .0001).

caption.p: Comparison of Autograft Sites to Within ±5 mm of the Glenoid’s Radius of Curvature a

fn.label: a
fn.p: Total number of measurements for each allograft site of a possible total of 34.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Values based on the Fisher exact test of the inferior coracoid, lateral coracoid, and iliac crest. All values were calculated using a paired analysis, matching each anatomic site to the respective measurement on the glenoid.

sec.title: Osteochondral Allograft Site Analysis
sec.p: Based on the interquartile range of the glenoid specimens, a graft with a radius of curvature <25 mm or >30 mm would have a curvature either too steep or too flat to re-create the native glenoid anatomy. However, a radius of curvature within the interquartile range of the glenoid would re-create the natural glenoid architecture in the majority of specimens. The unpaired analysis revealed that 94% (32/34 specimens) of the distal tibia, 68% (23/34 specimens) of the medial tibial plateau, 12% (4/34 specimens) of the S-DR, and 0% of both the L-DR and the radial head specimens were ideally congruent with the glenoid (Table 3).

caption.p: Comparison of Allograft Sites to the Glenoid’s Radius of Curvature a

fn.label: a
fn.p: Total number of measurements for each autograft and allograft site of a possible total of 34. All sites measured as independent variables (unpaired analysis).

fn.label: b
fn.p: Deemed as the number of measurements with a radius of curvature between 25 to 30 mm, based on the median interquartile range of the glenoid’s radius of curvature.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The ideal graft choice for glenoid augmentation in the setting of shoulder instability has yet to be clearly defined. To restore a patient’s glenohumeral joint as anatomically as possible, consideration should be given to the potential congruence of the graft source with the native glenoid. Although previous studies have defined the radii of curvature of the glenoid, inferior coracoid, and lateral distal tibia,8-10,15,24 this is, to our knowledge, the first study to directly compare both autograft and osteochondral allograft sites in the same setting as well as to determine the radius of curvature of several novel potential graft sites.

Of the 3 potential autograft sources measured in this study, only the inferior surface of the coracoid conformed with the glenoid’s radius of curvature. Not only did it have a similar median radius of curvature to the glenoid (25 vs 30 mm for G-SI; 25 vs 25 mm for G-AP), but paired analysis also revealed that it was within 5 mm of the glenoid’s radius of curvature in 59% and 94% of cases for the G-SI and G-AP, respectively. The median radii of curvature for both the lateral coracoid and inner table of the iliac crest were found to be >5 mm from the glenoid’s radius of curvature in all cases, proving to have poor conformity with the glenoid. Therefore, if the iliac crest is used for glenoid augmentation to replicate the anterior glenoid curvature, the surgeon should use an osteotome or bur to contour it, as described by Warner et al.31

Our data from the 5 potential osteochondral allograft sources closely correlate with those in the literature, finding excellent conformity between the lateral distal tibia and the glenoid.9,24 The median (interquartile range) radius of curvature of the distal tibia precisely matched that of the G-AP and closely matched the G-SI. Based on an ideal fit to the glenoid (defined as within the interquartile range of its radius of curvature), 94% of the distal specimens were ideally matched, while only 68% of the medial tibial plateau specimens and 12% of the specimens from the S-DR fell within range. None of the specimens from the other 2 sites that were examined (the radial head and the L-DR) conformed.

An important finding of this study is that the radius of curvature was found to be independent of the age, sex, height, or weight of each cadaveric specimen. This is significant and helps surgeons with the knowledge that, although humans are of varying shapes and sizes, their relative anatomic relationships are maintained. If one chooses fixation with an osteochondral allograft, a larger or smaller surface area of the graft may be required, but the curvature of the osteochondral surface will be equivalent across specimens.

Reports of the radius of curvature of the glenoid, coracoid, and distal tibia found in the literature closely correlate with our findings. Gooding et al10 examined the relationship between the glenoid and the undersurface of the coracoid in 210 cadaveric specimens using Mose circle measurements and in 20 living persons using 3-dimensional (3D) computed tomography (CT) radiographic measurements. Their study found that the radius of curvature of the inferior coracoid was 5 mm less than the glenoid (25 vs 30 mm) in the cadaveric measurements but was 1.4 mm larger than the glenoid (25.3 vs 23.9 mm) in 3D CT radiographic measurements. Additionally, this study validated Mose circles as a reliable tool for radius of curvature measurements. The original description and clinical application of an osteochondral allograft of the lateral distal tibia did not specify its anatomic congruity with the glenoid.24 However, a recent 3D CT analysis on 12 fresh-frozen cadaveric specimens specified their similarity, as no significant differences between the glenoid and the distal tibia with regard to the radius of curvature (25.9 vs 28.1 mm) or cartilage thickness (2.01 vs 2.29 mm) were found.9

There are several limitations to our study. The use of Mose circles to measure the radius of curvature assumes that each articular surface is a perfect sphere. Anatomically, different articulations vary in sphericity based on the plane and the site of measurement. For instance, Iannotti et al15 found that the humeral head was spherical in the center but that the peripheral radius was 2 mm less in the axial plane than in the coronal plane, and thus, the peripheral contour of the articular surface was found to be elliptical (ratio, 0.92). However, our use of Mose circles, in more than a single plane when necessary, was found to be a reliable measurement technique that provided consistent results with previously published data.10

Other limitations include the lack of advanced radiographic imaging, either through CT or magnetic resonance imaging, as an adjunct to this study. The cadaveric specimens used in this study did not have full body radiographic imaging to analyze, and no clinical comparison with age-matched controls was available. Our study was able to help identify which graft site could reapproximate the native glenoid anatomy in the majority of patients but was unable to provide answers as to differences in biomechanical strength or to the clinical importance of augmentation with a cartilaginous graft. Lastly, as with most cadaveric studies, there is a discrepancy between the patient age, bone density, and cartilage quality between the cadaveric specimens with those of the living population that sustains this injury. To account at least in part for these issues, we excluded 7 cadaveric specimens because of the presence of arthritis at 1 or more joints, with the other cadaveric specimens having preserved cartilaginous and osseous surfaces.

In conclusion, we found that the autograft of the inferior coracoid and the osteochondral allograft of the lateral distal tibia were ideal sites for glenoid augmentation based on their similar radii of curvature. The other sites that were examined proved to have a radius of curvature with a greater likelihood of being nearly or completely outside the ideal range of concavity of the glenoid. Further clinical studies directly comparing the inferior coracoid, the lateral distal tibia, and other potential sites must be conducted to determine differences in biomechanical stability and functional outcomes.

ack.p: The authors thank Marie Kane for her assistance in reviewing and editing this article.
